ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Jeff, Yeah, it looks like you hit the nail on the head.  Right now, it either completely chooses one parent or the other, but putting that code inside of

Hey Jeff,

Yeah, it looks like you hit the nail on the head.  Right now, it=

either completely chooses one parent or the other, but putting that
code i=
nside of the loop will make it treat each gene individually
(this will perf=
orm real crossover).

I'm going to put in the change and see how it changes=
 my experiments.
 Assuming it doesn't break anything, I'll roll this into t=
he next
version.  If it affects the results in a negative way, I'll make a
=
parameter for it so you can choose to use crossover or not.

Thanks for the=
 find!


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> > =
Well yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that randomChoice has
> > =
to be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e.
> > outs=
ide the big loop) then you choose links from either parent. But if
> > it i=
s inside the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from either
> > parent. =
Check this out and you will have a clearer picture if there is
> > a bug or=
 not. 
> 
> Thanks Petar. I am confident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the par=
ent
outside
> the loop, and thus grabs all links from either parent1 or par=
ent2.
What I am
> trying to find out is whether this is by design, or if it=
 is a bug.
> 
> Do you (or anyone else) happen to know how it works in othe=
r NEAT
packages,
> in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My guess is that=
 we are
supposed to
> be grabbing some links from parent1 and some other li=
nks from parent2,
> instead of one or the other. I can go check those packa=
ges, of
course, but I
> won't be able to do that for a little while and was=
 wondering if any
of you
> knew off the top of your heads.
> 
> > But the c=
loning issue is a deeper one. In this case you must ensure
> > that individ=
uals should not mate with themselves or such ones that
> > have zero compat=
ibility distance. Or at least try a few hundred times
> > to find a differe=
nt mate :) Hey, I say this to all users. Don't use
> > rand(), fuck that, u=
se the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed that in
> > enhances performance=
!
> 
> Fair enough, but right now I am more focused on the more immediate i=
ssue
> above. Thanks for the suggestions, though. I will delve into them wh=
en I
> resolve the other issue.
> 
> Thanks. Jeff. 
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> >=
 --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hi Pet=
ar-
> >> 
> >> Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (non-HyperNEAT) NEAT p=
ackage
> > around.
> >> Can you let me know if your NEAT implementation is =
different than
> > what I
> >> report below?
> >> 
> >> I am using Jason's =
HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here:
> >> 
> >> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/so=
ftware.html
> >> 
> >> If you download the package, the key file is:
> >> H=
yperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_GeneticIndividual.cpp
> >> 
> >> I am attaching it, =
but I don't know how that works with the yahoo
> > group.
> >> 
> >> Crosso=
ver occurs in this constructor:
> >> 
> >>     
> > GeneticIndividual::Gene=
ticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
> >> parent1,shared_ptr<Genetic=
Individual> parent2,bool
> > mate_multipoint_avg)
> >> 
> >> The following =
line occurs outside of the loop that goes through each
> > link:
> >> 
> >>=
  bool chooseFirstParent =3D (randomChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());
> >> =
 
> >> Then, inside the loop for each link:
> >> 
> >>                     =
if (chooseFirstParent)
> >>                     {
> >>                     =
    addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
> >>                     }
> >>      =
               else
> >>                     {
> >>                        =
 addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
> >>                     }
> >>  
> >> S=
o, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed from one parent or
> > the=

> >> other. Is that how it works in other versions of NEAT?
> >> 
> >> 
> =
>> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan=
 State University
> >> 
> >> jclune@
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >>> From: pe=
tar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@>
> >>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <=
neat@yahoogroups.com>
> >>> Date: Sun, 09 Nov 2008 20:14:32 -0000
> >>> To:=
 "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> >>> Subject: [neat] Re: Cr=
ossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and
> > PNEAT?
> >>> 
> >>> Hi Jeff, 
>=
 >>> 
> >>> Well I don't know about the exact implementations of HyperNEAT =
you
> > are
> >>> using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutati=
ons
> >>> disabled), but in principle crossover should choose genes randoml=
y
> >>> from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the child. In
=
> >>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
> > reg=
ular
> >>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based on th=
e
> >>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and mutate the
> > =
CPPNs.
> >>> But in the case you get lots of individuals with equal fitness=
, I
> >>> guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the code frequently
>=
 >>> chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try to avoid this
> >=
 by
> >>> introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a "father" tha=
t
> > are
> >>> not compatible with the mother, that is, when their compati=
bility
> >>> distance is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility, sim=
ply
> >>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced
> > n=
etwork is
> >>> changed in such a magnitude that is has no chance for survi=
val and
> > is
> >>> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> >>> 
> >=
>> Peter
> >>> 
> >>> 
> >>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclun=
e@> wrote:
> >>>> 
> >>>> Hello all-
> >>>> 
> >>>> Does crossover do anyth=
ing in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>> 
> >>>> PNEAT:
> >>>> If I am reading th=
e code correctly, during crossover, if the
> >>> substrates are
> >>>> the =
same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is always the
> > case
> >>> =
in
> >>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either parent1 or=

> >>> parent2.
> >>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some=
 from parent1
> >>> and some
> >>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just on=
e?
> >>>> 
> >>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right? I=
t will
> >>> always grab
> >>>> the substrate of parent1 or the substrate o=
f parent2.  If I track
> >>> parent and
> >>>> offspring fitness, 100% of t=
he time the child has the exact same
> >>> fitness as
> >>>> one of the two=
 parents.
> >>>> 
> >>>> On to HyperNEAT:
> >>>> 
> >>>> I tracked the fitn=
ess of each parent and the resulting offspring.
> >>> The odd
> >>>> thing =
is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e. they are
> >>> never
> >>=
>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their parents
> >>> 98.=
88% of the
> >>>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 tha=
t were
> >>> crossed over
> >>>> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't=
 it? Why would these
> > new
> >>> links
> >>>> have such a small impact? I=
t turns out that this is because
> > nearly
> >>> every
> >>>> time that th=
ere is an extra link that gets placed in the child,
> > the
> >>> parent
> =
>>>> that donated that link is also the parent whose weights are being
> >>=
> grabbed,
> >>>> meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent (he=
nce the
> >>> same
> >>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be=
 much more
> >>> disruptive, no?
> >>>> 
> >>>> 
> >>>> As a final test, I =
did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the
> >>> default
> >>>> 'Mutate=
OnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
> > never
> >>> are
>=
 >>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
> >>>> h=
yperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
> > MutateOnlyProbability
> >>=
>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over. Despite my
> >>> c=
omments
> >>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, ho=
wever
> >>> the
> >>>> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem=
 to be
> >>> statistically
> >>>> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was=
 true. Nevertheless,
> > this
> >>> is not a
> >>>> perfect test of whether=
 crossover pays dividends, because if
> >>> crossover does
> >>>> nothing m=
ost of the time, and I increase MutateOnlyProbability
> > from
> >>> .25 to=

> >>>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> > cro=
ssed
> >>> orgs are
> >>>> also mutated).
> >>>> 
> >>>> Are these the inte=
nded consequences of crossover, or am I missing
> >>> something?
> >>>> 
> =
>>>> Cheers,
> >>>> Jeff Clune
> >>>> 
> >>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michig=
an State University
> >>>> 
> >>>> jclune@
> >>>>
